title-group.article-title: Teaching Journalism Students How to Tell Indigenous Stories in an Informed Way
title-group.subtitle: A Work Integrated Learning Approach

abstract.p: Australian journalism schools are full of students who have never met an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Island person and who do not know their history. Journalism educators are ill-equipped to redress this imbalance as a large majority are themselves non-Indigenous and many have had little or no experience with the coverage of Indigenous issues or knowledge of Indigenous affairs. Such a situation calls for educational approaches that can overcome these disadvantages and empower journalism graduates to move beyond the stereotypes that characterize the representation of Indigenous people in the mainstream media. This article will explore three different courses in three Australian tertiary journalism education institutions, which use Work-Integrated Learning Approaches to instil the cultural competencies necessary to encourage a more informed reporting of Indigenous issues. The findings from the three projects illustrate the importance of adopting a collaborative approach by industry, the Indigenous community and educators to encourage students’ commitment to quality journalism practices when covering Indigenous issues.

bio.p: Heather Stewart, PhD, is an award-winning journalist and visiting fellow at Queensland University of Technology where she is the principal researcher in a 2010 AIATSIS grant. She was the joint project leader of the UQ Indigenous Voice Project, 2009–10, which had a work-integrated learning approach. The project won the UQ Equity Award and was highly commended in the UQ Trailblazers Awards E-mail: h4.stewart@qut.edu.au

Michael Williams was the joint Indigenous Voice 2009–10 UQ Project leader. He was the UQ Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies unit director 1992–2010. He is a member of the Goorang Goorang Aboriginal community from the country between Gladstone and Bundaberg in southeast Queensland. He also served as an AIATSIS councillor and on the Special Broadcasting Services (SBS) board.

Trevor Cullen, PhD, Associate Professor of Journalism, is Programme Director for Communications and Head of Journalism at Edith Cowan University. His contributions to student learning have been recognized with university and national tertiary teaching awards and research grants. Prof Cullen is also the author of more than 25 peer-reviewed articles, book chapters and conference papers on reporting HIV.

Michelle Johnston is a lecturer in Film, Television and Screen Arts at Curtin University. With many years of experience working in mainstream television, she now specializes in teaching an undergraduate television production course. She is currently working on a PhD project that explores Indigenous Community Media with a focus on the urban Perth Noongar community.

Gail Phillips, PhD, is Associate Professor of Journalism at Murdoch University. She was a radio journalist for 14 years. In 2007, she received the Vice-Chancellor’s award for excellence in teaching. She was lead researcher of the five-university Reporting Diversity project team, funded by the Department of Immigration and Citizenship to examine how the Australian media report on cultural diversity (2005–09).

Pauline Mulligan, PhD, was the UQ Indigenous Voice 2009–10 project manager. She has led research projects in environmental issues at the Universities of Newcastle and the Melbourne and currently is collaborating in research on science communication in Journalism.

Leo Bowman, PhD, is an Associate Professor in Journalism at the Queensland University of Technology. He is an experienced journalist and has been centrally involved with a strong journalism production suite offered at QUT. He has written a range of academic papers including some on Work Place Learning and conducted a number of journalism-based cross cultural exchanges.

Michael Meadows teaches Journalism in the School of Humanities at Griffith University. He worked as a journalist for 10 years before moving into academia in 1987. His research interests have ranged from perspectives on journalism in the media representation of Indigenous people, Indigenous media history, policy and production, community media processes, the role of the colonial press in imagining the Australian landscape and the first systematic study of Work Integrated Learning in Australia in 2010.
